newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: PRESS DIGEST - SOUTH AFRICA - SEPT 23.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - SOUTH AFRICA - SEPT 23.

text.p: These are the leading stories in the South African press on Monday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- A group of South African petrochemical and oil companies are poised to make a decision this week on whether to pursue a Taiwanese proposal for a $3.5 billion greenfields petrochemical complex to be built somewhere on the South African coast.

- Romatex Ltd , which is controlled by C.G. Smith Ltd, has been sold to Consolidated Frame Textiles Ltd (Confram) for 2.25 rand a share, wiping more than 75 percent off Romatex's net asset value which stood at 9.77 rand a share at the end of the company's March half-year.
- The European Commission has blocked a $78 million loan to Iscor Ltd 6.8 billion rand Saldanha Bay steel project, casting a pall over free trade negotiations between Europe and South Africa.
- UK-based merchant bank SBC Warburg has scored another coup with its appointment as an adviser to the post, telecommunications and broadcasting ministry.

- The takeover of Romatex, the troubled textile manufacturer, by Confram has been concluded at 2.25 rand a share -- less than a quarter the net asset value of 10 rand a share and 31.8 percent below Friday's closing price of 3.30 rand -- sources close to the companies said on Sunday.

- The South African Broadcasting Corp (SABC) may have to close some of its African language broadcast stations and reduce other public broadcasting responsibilities to compensate for the loss of revenue following the privatisation of six of its regional stations, which together account for about 90 million rand in profit.

- South African agricultural bodies said on Friday that they had no knowledge of negotiated deals worth $100 million for the import of South African agricultural products, claimed by a visiting Iranian delegation earlier this month.
- An overwhelming 93 percent of readers who have responded to the newspaper's "Tell it to the President" survey have demanded a national referendum on the re-introduction of the death penalty.

- A meeting between the African national Congress and the Inkatha Freedom Party to discuss finalisation of the constitution was necessary to ensure stability, IFP leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi said on Sunday.
- Former deputy minister Bantu Holomisa lashed out at the ANC for not taking Gauteng premier Tokyo Sexwale to a disciplinary hearing to investigate what he knows about drug trafficking.
